newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada loses WTO appeal on Sports Illustrated.
newsitem.headline: Canada loses WTO appeal on Sports Illustrated.

text.p: Canada said on Monday it lost an appeal at the World Trade Organisation (WTO) on taxes it imposes on Canadian editions of U.S. magazines like Sports Illustrated.

A government statement said the WTO also ruled in favour of the United States in rejecting postal subsidies Ottawa offered to Canadian publications. The original WTO panel decision in March had favoured Canada on the subsidies issue.

"We've just received the ruling and will have to look at it carefully to assess our options," said Canadian Heritage Minister Sheila Copps, adding that Canada would seek new ways to attain Canada's cultural policy objectives in ways that are consistent with the ruling.
The United States had launched the WTO complaint against a law enacted in December 1995 which imposed an 80 percent tax on advertising in U.S. periodicals that publish editions in Canada.
The law targeted Time Warner Inc.'s Sports Illustrated by referring to so-called split runs that started after March 26, 1993, just days before Sports Illustrated Canada first came out.

"This decision is a real blow to Canadian culture and shows us clearly what's wrong with these trade agreements," said Maude Barlowe, chairwoman of the Council of Canadians, a non-profit group that encourages protectionist policies.
